document.title: Religion Curriculum 2014 Archdiocese of Seattle Catholic Schools

D317BE55AF2648F9822EEE9B6C5623B4.description:
Recognize the New Evangelization calls each of us to deepen our faith,
believe in the Gospel message and go forth to proclaim the Gospel.

EBF4548C504A44C8BDCABE7FC300D746.description: Show understanding of one’s beliefs through the profession of one’s faith.

661EECEE1FA94E31B8B208807544E137.description: Be able to distinguish their Catholic Christian faith from other Christian faiths.

AD56712B514744608EE3703FE3C661C1.description:
Understand and explain why Christians pray and work for Christian unity and
the need to respect people of all faiths.

38CB4C5D878D415CB29F7C80097DFF8A.description:
Recall and understand the implications for your own life that Jesus
commanded the disciples to “go and make disciples of all nations.”

4A7E5B281D6A4173ABC6616D5A878B9A.description:
Describe how ecumenism and dialogue are evangelizing works of the Church
in the task of creating unity and peace in the world.

6C1F28C03BD84441A2B463C21C2511DC.description:
Describe the difference between ecumenical dialogue and inter-religious
dialogue.

35DBB4A6683743C3A9FBBBB6C357340B.description:
Articulate an understanding of the Rites of the Catholic Church as an
expression of unity and diversity.

6DD5000EB6CE4E2DBDAB5A987FFE5643.description:
CALL TO
ECUMENISM,
INTERFAITH
DIALOGUE AND THE
NEW
EVANGELIZATION
[848-849,927-
933,905,2044,2472]

A902EFA2ECF64100A4BCEFF42386A97C.description: Explain the stewardship equation – receive / cultivate / share / return.

414666B77C7C4205853FBD45B4E12835.description:
Explain how humans have been called by God to be stewards of all of God’s
creation.

42C731CA7EEE47A1A6E1F2B24695A7A4.description:
CALL TO
STEWARDSHIP AND
SERVICE: Catholic
social teaching about
the common good
[2419-2422]

CC081A442C1F473AA2C3AE99A5B883D2.description:
Recognize charisms come through the grace of the Holy Spirit to be used for
the building of the Church.

C0B26AD63DD14203948F2F8551C95185.description:
Articulate that at Baptism we receive a special call from the Holy Spirit to
proclaim, witness, and serve the Church and the world given our unique gifts.

074964C879D242D88550054E69904ED5.description:
BAPTISMAL CALL AND
DISCIPLESHIP (the
mandate to go forth)
[816,849]
Scripture
Mt. 5:11-12; 28:16-20
Lk. 11:1
Jn. 13:15

3AE94CB8E9F7404DBD4F34CC5FAAFEF2.description:
TASK OF CATECHESIS 6: THE CHURCH’S MISSIONARY LIFE AND SERVICE: Students acquire and demonstrate skills to recognize their gifts from God and their
vocation to share the good News of Jesus Christ in word and deed in the world.

CE9F8F8AE8A04F089D60436E6F7CEDEB.description: Discuss Mary as she is portrayed in the Magnificat.

C9DC38FF6E6E44D8B14442F13D8994B1.description: Recognize symbols of Mary in art from around the world.

8B44B3D15FEF4AC984C43C1157FD79F2.description: Recognize and identify the Mary as the Mother of the Church and our mother.

4F898F6CC7B84C0BB69674A50901173E.description: Celebrate devotional days in honor of Mary.

30F2669BE8AF4ECCAF1B56EB51A4BFF1.description:
Tell the story, identify qualities and celebrate the feast day of the parish patron
saint.

7E789103F5D04D1F99E0AD11DEB0AF05.description:
Identify ways that we can act now and could act in the future as Christ would act
with an impact on the good of all God’s people.

B7ED194BA8A54807AEE02D7266F67B6D.description:
Apply the concept of being made in God’s image to the response to God’s call
through vocation.

34605E8672F44B2BBAD6FFB5CD4BFA82.description:
Know that we are called to participate in the life of the Church and discern how
God helps us to know our vocation (discernment).

1490FF6921914EF2AC495911CCD7319C.description:
Vocation:
Marriage, Priesthood
and the Religious Life
[914-933]
Scripture
Mt. 9:10-13
Mk. 1:16-20
Jn 1:35-51
2 Cor. 4:4

6D1B69609BAA464B824BBFEE1EA0E6E1.description: Recognize that all are called by God to be Saints.

C65D578455F049CE9F5B7EB648DEC8BA.description:
Identify and describe the qualities of holy men and women in Scripture and
throughout Church history and describe ways we can live out these qualities in our own lives.

E3246101728C4C99A1E58276194A0C0F.description:
The
Universal Call to
Holiness
[2013-2014,2028,2813]
Scripture
Mt. 5:48
2 Tim. 4: 1-8
Rm. 8: 28-30

B7268DD366F94A148FB62257A0E4B22F.description:
Cite and associate references in Paul Letters emphasizing the importance of
family and the definition of domestic church.

19452DCC074A491E922A97385B0B1E6D.description:
Locate and cite passages in the Bible that show us how we are to live as
Disciples of Christ.

368422595ABA4D67BF64DA8AE4BA9D86.description:
Name the Precepts of the Church and identify ways that the precepts
strengthen the Church to live out a Christian life as God’s people (priest, prophet and king.)

AED3FABA4AF04A26910416F7902435F9.description:
Explain the function of Papal Encyclicals, Pastoral Letters and the Catholic
Catechism as vehicles for the unity of the Church.

20B6DECA9F66497788E2523BA42F5B29.description:
Identify the names and roles of leadership in the Church moving from the Pope
to the Pastor.

4A026B3A0B11412497E3116D10E179E7.description:
Church
Order: The Hierarchy -
Magisterium and
Infallibiilty
[874-896]

D82741CE7DB74109B9BD987731864DA7.description:
CHRIST’S
FAITHFUL –
HEIRARCHY, LAITY,
CONSECRATED LIFE:
[871-945]

5DAECE9F09B34063B4DE60C4C830653A.description:
Explain the four marks of the Church and how they move us towards the
universal call to salvation

BAB16AF794674C908BCA7CACB354A805.description:
Understand that catholic (lower case “c”) means universal and is identified with
the world-wide Church, which includes many cultures and ethnic groups.

53AB193882FD475EA1B6318E1394EBC0.description:
Recall and describe the four marks of the Church: one, holy, catholic,
apostolic.

9FB2F5F4EEB74B77ACA10BA78F1C9560.description:
THE
MYSTERY AND MARKS
OF THE CHURCH:
ONE, HOLY, CATHOLIC
AND APOSTOLIC
[811-870]
Scripture
Mt. 16: 13-20

747ED81AA7EF4F4EB787FD5BCB00A790.description:
Appreciate the benefits of chastity/chaste lives with maintaining our bodies as
Temples of the Holy Spirit.

4548845F57D140F18300B7561DF12769.description:
Temple of
the Holy Spirit
[797-801]
Scripture
Eph. 1:4; 2:21-23;5:25-
27
Mt. 19:6
2:Cor 6:16; 1 Cor 3:16-
17

AC24BBDB4FE04642A52D77F872AF01B5.description:
Identify the responsibility of the Body of Christ to work for the Kingdom of God
on Earth throughout history, today, and in the future.

EBD56BC3E4E640BCAF25BE32D187A51E.description:
Identify holy men and women of the Church through the ages who have
demonstrated concern for the poor and marginalized and in turn acted as Christ and made an
impact for the good.

A416B744DC434361A2552E94690F6D66.description: People of God [781-786] Scripture Acts 10:34-35 1 Pet. 2:9 1 Jn. 3:3-5 1 Cor. 11:25

97FD64C0E3AA473A8D034643110518BB.description:
Trace the history of the Catholic faith in Florida, and know the history of
one’s parish, recognizing how each person helps shape Church history.

2FFD96775F7D40548F8DA2A97A8A87B3.description:
Explore the role of Religious Orders through the ages: Hermits, Monks,
Monastics, Mendicants, and Missionaries.

9F5C033B13EE46F89E6FC03E7663BF45.description:
Know and understand the importance of the sixteen documents from the Vatican
Council II.

FF552BBB73534F7897233EFB75C60F5E.description:
Show understanding of the causes of the Reformation, the rise of Protestantism
and the Counter-Reformation of the Catholic Church to begin the inner work of reform begun in
the Council of Trent in the age of reform from 1517 to 1891 CE.

369DDB0291B8496BB226171DE93460E4.description:
Explore moments of transition in the life of the Church to include: 1054 Schism;
Avignon Papacy; Mendicant Orders; Reformation; Infallible Statements of the Church.

82AD3BF0FBE4446BA63B01EFB764DC0E.description: Explain how the councils were occasions for renewal in the Church.

B22FCAF688DD4561A87D9B07CE388007.description: Explore the role of the Pope in leading the Church.

79DACB216FA14C908078F96E92242C76.description: Show familiarity with the geography and cities of middle eastern world and Rome.

2CC61AD2DD3A46B499422B7601622F7B.description:
Know that the Acts of the Apostles give insight into the early Church, and identify
the differences between the ministry of Peter and Paul.

1E82C4DD4A4E47BAAF89AA2D2899B080.description:
Demonstrate a basic understanding of Church history through an overview of Early
Church Acts; Council of Jerusalem; Paul’s Journeys’ growth and change through the ages.

A7C78795F0ED486B98295027FE3B7F19.description:
Create a timeline the early period of the Church from 30 CE to 313 CE, the role of
the deacons, Roman persecutions, move from Jewish to Gentile membership, the contributions
of the early fathers, and the importance of councils.

78EB4422B5A340F2B268374C30B3ADE4.description:
Know the story of Pentecost and how the Church began in the Old Testament and
New Testament.

99CCE24C73E64AF18800BE7255FE8A0F.description:
Give examples of how the Church continues to teach as Jesus did and recognize
how each person helps shape Church history.

780F57E04A774244B2A7663E9F0A11B5.description:
THE CHURCH
IN GOD’S PLAN
[748-780
Church History
[758-780]
Scripture
Epistles
Acts 2:1-42

C5BEF6D8656E4B599C74C00AE91E4365.description:
TASK OF CATECHESIS 5: EDUCATION FOR COMMUNITY LIFE: Students study and participate in the life and mission of the church, the Body of
Christ and the community of believers, as expressed in the Church’s origin, history, ecclesiology, the Communion of Saints and their family, the domestic church.

24D6CFC238A64898B3A4A73262AC0381.description: Agnus Dei / Behold the Lamb of God

079BA9980CDC4DBAB20B460FBD6BE646.description: Responses after Scripture: Readings and Gospel

F1E9D4FDAC604564809CE74F4D747202.description: Spontaneous Prayer using “You, Who, Do Through” sequence

B08274000CA04B99B3CC8FDD6E03D833.description:
Invitatory, Psalm(s) antiphonal style and Doxology – Psalm 90 and Canticle of Mary
the Magnificat (Lk 1:46-55) from Liturgy of the Hours

59B9C68684974A6B8E1A13E59C7144B2.description: One or more decades of the Rosary

EA0B486BC6CF4C9296806DBA5769DFBB.description: Prayers of blessing, adoration, praise, intercession, thanksgiving, petition

80C4C4F187E040A480BCFC8DEE1AEAEE.description: Review of all prayers by hear

841715339E42419281AB9E933F15CE82.description:
PRAYERS WE
KNOW BY HEART,
EXPERIENCE AND
SHARE AT MASS

B05518240F9C4EB9BF3AFBB5EF45DD2B.description: Understand how icons can assist us with prayer.

CBBDB40EF56340469478B81C2DDF82DD.description: Participate and/or lead the Liturgy of the Hours.

E6A5AAD7AF604F0790BFF74C56F8F2EF.description: Identify the connection between St. Dominic and the Rosary

882D0722CBFB42E6A1C14B3A85119CE3.description: Articulate all the mysteries of the Rosary.

F27AB3C39686484CA4F481E0569AF15E.description: Understand the role of the Liturgy of the Hours in the monastic life.

FBFE248C4AFC42D6912A043F4B2E8FD4.description: Pray a variety of prayers associated with different saints.

4FBB7772B3FA4298938BE549D06A2664.description: Participate in variety of traditional devotions.

9100A3BBC04149E1AF1379C91090D3BB.description:
DEVOTIONAL
PRACTICES (e.g.
rosary, stations of the
cross, novenas)
[1200-1209, 1674-1679,
2683-2696]

D2AF0F8104C949848612F3B1074EA141.description:
Explain why the Our Father is the model of all prayer for us and summarizes our
Catholic Christian faith.

790AAD4D91CD49188557AB8BCC762C9F.description:
OUR FATHER: A
Summary of the Gospel
[2746-2865]
Scripture
Mt. 6:5-15

6592B3624BF54B4D86B2A875ACE26E9C.description: Identify the four movements of Lectio Divina

2A75B22CA5694DAFA3BD166AF14E48A3.description:
Identify how the Church’s tradition of prayer at daily intervals was meant to remind
Christians that all time is holy.

2AE96554C8554F0BBE0F41B6ACE8A0C4.description:
Explore, experience and reflect on the various expressions of prayer: vocal,
meditative and contemplative.

A21A7E4D6F1940BAB5E637AF3169E387.description: Identify the diversity and development of prayer expressions within the Church.

0CD49728D0124FD794E177081493F425.description: State how we use the prayers of the saints to help us pray.

1A938A8150D14657BB8B560B8078EC82.description:
EXPRESSIONS OF
PRAYER (vocal,
meditation,
contemplation,
personal and shared)
[2700-2724]

D684676C9C214769A333DC84D6C6429C.description: Write prayers demonstrating the six forms of prayer.

7EC48B5AB8F04BE4B95E535CC1E85AD3.description:
Attend and reflect on one of the following: Benediction; Stations of the Cross;
adoration.

7568D52DE9CC4734AB9746527BE7C2F5.description:
Articulate how all prayer forms helps us lead holy lives through blessing, adoration,
petition, intercessions, thanksgiving and praise.

0B9E6A704FCB44CB82898CB3C597037C.description:
FORMS OF PRAYER
(Blessing, Adoration
Petition, Intercession
Thanksgiving, Praise)
[2623-2649]

D34331673BF94CD09B3FAAC3885C47A4.description: Show understanding that prayer is a way of life.

CB3F4CF91D8B4EBD9C83FD3405BEF360.description: Discover and share sources for prayer.

BDB5D608F3FB4F6EAE48DF8FC402DA2E.description: Describe how prayer leads to an honest and intentional response to our lives.

6E764CBE196747E7A7D41BB1F1B67166.description:
UNIVERSAL
CALL TO PRAYER,
IMPORTANCE OF
PRAYER
[2558-2758]
Scripture
Mt. 6:9-13; 11:25-26;
14:23
Mk. 1:35
Lk. 6:12; 22:41-44
Jn. 17:1-26

79559D86A37A4BE38CDDEC5770526643.description:
TASK OF CATECHESIS 4 – TEACHING TO PRAY: Students experience and engage in Catholic expressions of prayer to deepen their relationship
with God and the Church.

8F63E3AFAFDF4A269E4BDBF0C71BE316.description:
Identify Catholic Social Teaching as beginning with Pope Leo XIII in his
encyclical Rerum Novarum.

71C4B98674B5433D9D4FAE6261D2697E.description:
Identify holy people from Scripture, and reflect on their lives using the model of
encounter, disturbance and response. (Resource: Maryknoll Missionaries)

B3C6DD86EB45475C955C97DFC1DB6278.description:
Apply the concept of the dignity of the worker to the moral mandate to work for
the benefit of the community.

E15CA480169F4BB5B928D2FE2363998D.description:
Explain how Catholics are called to protect and promote the dignity of all human
life.

51879B9313FF44839954170A2113DF4B.description:
Explain causes of vulnerability (age, race, disability, etc.) and ways that we can
act morally in situations where vulnerable people are present.

82AB9B39EE404215B86ECDD54F43DC59.description:
Explain how the social teachings of the Church help them to understand the
biblical message of God’s saving love.

DA51E98F650A4D9E9AA7CC716255DEE9.description:
Apply the principles of the right to life and the dignity of the human person to
the formation of a moral conscience.

750B1A3C3E8E4C42AC9A8ED2D0A8C1BA.description:
Participate in service projects and offer reflections on how serving others
continues in building the Kingdom of God on earth.

89A457C186A544058D2F4C01FEA16EFD.description:
Identify and research persons/groups that have influenced society/culture for the
good throughout Church history.

F9D7BFB9748245388138917BAD999671.description:
Recognize how the Church continues to work toward understanding the issues
and problems of today in light of the Church’s Social Teachings.

DCAEE01743424211836AB84B00CC5801.description:
Know and explain how to incorporate the seven principles of Catholic Social
Teachings into our lives.

FFB89C8F60474048A79E41D96FF52DE9.description:
Understand meaning of stewardship and how one acts as a “steward” of God’s
creation in caring for and sharing of personal belongings, classroom, school building, and
parish grounds.

CC761DEC772247739333EACD3F0A6CB3.description:
Explain how their creation in God’s image underlies Catholic Social Teaching
(innate dignity of all humans.)

97A87D12CAA042B8A0F83DFBD8910895.description:
Give examples of the special place of human beings as stewards of God’s
creation.

7B1FCE95DA544AC5A7E1C0F75A0C4CB2.description:
Catholic
Social Teachings –
Consistent Ethic of
Life, Love of
Neighbor, and
Corporal and
Spiritual Works of
Mercy
[2419-2449]
Scripture
Ex. 22:20-26
Mt. 25:31-46
Lk. 4:1-22

D299380B804740EA820D8A59933F3B2B.description:
Associate and explain the terms “cleansing” with purgatory and “self-exclusion”
with hell.

A864BB7D37C14310B49874563663FB98.description:
Explain how sin separate us from a good relationship with God, and inhibits us
from responding to the call of salvation by God through Jesus.

ED685E028A68470B9E0CADED8AB7166F.description:
Give examples from Church history of how sin separates us from God’s promise
of salvation and reconciliation brings us back.

E5F5781237DB468BB43F734266ECBE9D.description:
Identify and articulate the morality of human (personal) acts and how both venial
and mortal sin can result in social sin.

EF701E2D66904E0CA3381A25F59F59B0.description:
Personal
and Social Sin
[1846-1876]
Scripture
Ps. 9
Mt. 13:50
Lk. 10:25-37
Jn. 4:5-42

C40F2F68425648DB87FD464B7EF66537.description: Explain in your own words the importance of common good within our world.

8C90D8ADDCB94D23A623B476E70F6BD8.description: Identify a saint who exemplifies a specific virtue.

E8BFCCDA340D46E0B4E3A65C7142C75F.description:
Identify a virtue you strive to live out in daily life and explain how this virtue helps
you grow as a person.

87338D01B72340E0A3BF0C32C56319A7.description: Demonstrate virtuous living as a way to opening to God’s grace.

3B0816BAA326442EA6C2567103B9E71C.description:
Virtues –
Cardinal and
Theological
[1803-1845, 2656-
2662]
Scripture
Lk. 15:11-32
Ph. 4:8
1 Cor. 13:1-13

C7AC64F6BB0A4847A853B038796D4447.description:
Formulate a moral code for life based on the teachings of Jesus, the
Commandments, and the teachings of the Church.

8E126BE91F0E4089B5FC4AA75C51FB1D.description:
Understand and explain the Ten Commandments as the moral law that was
given to Israel.

4A6ED3DA130F41FFBE485910482D0AE2.description:
Covenant
and the Ten
Commandments
[2052-2557]
Scripture
Ex. 19:16-20:17;
24:1-12
Mt. 22:34-40
Mk. 12:28-34

F1247069789F43A2819757FBD4533C89.description:
Make connections with the Beatitudes and Ten Commandments, explain the
moral guidance given by God through Moses and Jesus, and how this can be lived out in our
lives.

6260EAAD87BC48368F6BBC83F182CD9E.description:
Review and list the Spiritual and Corporal Works of Mercy as ways to form
conscience.

2742C4B2C9544A84AD2F0C0E03710E33.description:
Review and identify a moral decision-making process which includes reflection
on faith, law, context and self/others.

92AECAF4E2554D759DC8F54C591890D4.description:
Describe free will and the corresponding responsibilities to choose wisely and to
form our conscience throughout our lives.

9EC39D4D35124EB894E3478960F33F48.description:
Prepare for, participate in, and reflect on the Sacrament of
Penance/Reconciliation.

FA0BDA9F11AB4D1AA87775A449583A22.description:
List, and define each of the seven capital sins and how the Cardinal and
Theological Virtues strengthen us to avoid these sins.

2B0FF74D393240FFA3EF7247B6F6E68A.description:
Describe the moral and natural law that is written and engraved in the soul of
every man; it is human reason telling Him to do good and avoid evil.

233452ACC46244DDA279F5F66B7F642D.description:
Describe consequences of positive and negative behaviors/actions and how sin
affects the whole community.

CED9190DD8D241668E7337FED2C6537C.description: Define sin as turning away from God and reconciliation as turning back to God.

1EA994486F3B418CAD65A8A938EC4364.description: Reflect upon life and describe the need for healing.

62120F23DAC948FB99532D695F163891.description:
Identify and describe how conscience is a function of reason that allows one to be
responsible for one’s actions.

DF0524EABBCA49E7B7390A032EA29234.description:
Human
Freedom and
Conscience
Formation
[1030-1037, 1730-
1802]
Scripture
Mt. 5:1-12
Mk. 2:1-12; 4:1-20
Rm. 2:12-15

4594E0347BD3476B87F6F56001DCF14C.description:
Articulate how happiness is found in serving others in the name of Christ and
how the Beatitudes challenge and show us the path to authentic happiness.

BF6C1FB877004A288611CF4668010F96.description:
Recall that God made human beings with freedom to act responsibly when
confronted with moral choices.

EB34F236E07643DF85E44B10D5A97CB8.description:
Describe how the Church’s opposition to abortion and capital punishment is
consistent with the belief that all life is sacred.

7BAD6FE7A88F422BA3BCEBF6FC80B55F.description:
Articulate why all life is deserving of reverence and demonstrate an
understanding of the church’s stance on the sanctity of life, and how this is consistent with
scripture and tradition (right to life, human dignity, preferential option for the poor.)

486EC7F09B5449A3A90C6458F387287D.description: Explain how saints model the authentic love to will the good of the other.

88DED5459E5740DE984C5B293097EE1B.description:
Explain how God calls each to act in a loving way toward one another, and know
what it means to be a “Child of God’.

EB89E92E13784F0B89CD3273EB5E94E2.description:
Made in
the Image of God –
Foundation of
Human Dignity
[355-368,1004,1700-
1876]
Scripture
Gen. 1:27
Mt. 7:12; 10:24

FCBE299C46514C369905B8D776C4A78C.description: Describe the Natural Law as it relates to moral development.

1430C60283D04E7CA91E8D06B158DABF.description: Recall authentic human love is to will the good of the other.

67B495BC4CFE4167A4102719E789E641.description:
Describe how faith helps me to face the hardships of suffering, disappointment
and tragedy.

C27E44D5A8BB4808B127DAB0274792AA.description:
Articulate how God made each of us with the desire and capacity to respond to
the gift of faith.

3F9803E03C93483CA8A7869C5B46C652.description:
TASK OF CATECHESIS 3 – MORAL EDUCATION: Students develop a moral conscience that is informed by Church teachings and conformed to Christ,
as modeled in a personal life of virtue and demonstrated in service of the Gospel’s demands for society

BD8801C29C5C46F5AB5BFEA25D2CB1CD.description: Show familiarity with leading prayer using the Book of Blessings.

73531E6DFB6945BD93F679134DC27418.description:
Attend, reflect and describe various liturgies in the Church: funeral, weddings,
ordination, dedications, and benediction.

955499A217E2488EA90E8B06A717CB40.description:
Liturgical
Rites: Weddings,
[1621-1637]
Funerals, [988-1029,
1680-1690] and
Blessings [1671-
1673]

43E7CD7D17634B9FB23D1A11E8DB9CA5.description:
Antiphonally, pray the Psalms from the Liturgy of the Hours including those
learned in previous grades and Psalm 90. Reflect on the Canticle of Mary, the Magnificat within
the Liturgy of the Hours.

E5761F1A84404A3DB267DEEF1825F557.description:
Explain the importance of the Liturgy of the Hours for the Catholic Church and for
all Christians.

71C973B1F1A7484BB44A71F33A422DF0.description:
Experience and leading the Liturgy of the Hours using Shorter Christian Prayer
format for morning prayer, lauds or evening prayer, vespers.

399E735E9C6C41FBB894B115AD5CD423.description:
Divine Office
Liturgy of the Hours
[1174-1178] Scripture:
Psalms 8, 90
Lk. 1:68-79 (Canticle
of Zechariah
Lk 1:46-55 (Canticle
of Mary, the
Magnificat

B644A0B1F68C42E8B5991217B5E342CB.description: Use sacramentals to enrich prayer life.

BF0AE601788C45A280EF73BB7BEDE6A6.description:
Identify the symbols and sacramentals in the parish church and associate them
with parts of the Eucharist and other sacraments.

D4ACEC2E708E4355A61D1F4D2E85E79E.description: Identify aspects of an appropriate liturgical environment.

7430A347B13C49F09537CAFFE11859A2.description: Understand that memorials recognize the lives of saints in the Liturgical Calendar.

8830FD3DE18F4A688E54A5E0DD6F6ED9.description:
Differentiate between the solemnity, feasts and memorials in the Liturgical
Calendar.

99647EE9038D496DBDCCBB63B169D740.description:
Describe the liturgical year and know the purpose, sequence and significance of
the seasons and colors.

0223FF8395804CEBB9F984F48B7E992A.description:
Recall and understand that Catholic marriages are called to witness to the
Trinitarian love of Christ.

082D6BC1232D4D20A181E59DFC834F69.description:
Understand that priests promise to be celibate to give themselves fully to God and
to be of service to God’s people.

E9640169F34641F889A2B884DC00A83C.description:
Explain the connection between the Sacrament of Holy Orders and apostolic
succession.

A64496A7272447E7981FD52109B4B847.description:
Sacraments
at the Service of
Communion
[1533-1666]
Scripture
1 Peter 2:9
Mk. 12:28-34
Act 6:1-6

4CDEF25F9DEE4E64B010489E8C561874.description: Observe and reflect on the Sacrament of Healing (Anointing).

19CC5FE737D14DFF97032E1FC1DB7EFD.description:
Prepare for and participate in the Sacrament of Reconciliation and explain the
importance of this sacrament throughout life.

D916C86D47E0484A859AE8EE1B24736D.description: Associate the Sacrament of Confirmation with the Pentecost story.

77728191753448B8B8510EEE7B3A8EE0.description:
Describe a Eucharistic community as one in which its members seek to be nourished
by Jesus and realize they are sent to serve.

54E53A3496784B1AB1C907FB5977D0C7.description:
Explain how participation in the Eucharist allows us to be given nourishment by Jesus
to live out our call to be disciples.

96B43FDDCA1A4FF0AC4577D4935F0C0F.description: Identify the importance of Baptism as the entryway to life as a Christian.

CFD602CBCC7C42E6B6C08DDEB5900568.description: Research and explain how the Church has been the custodian of sacraments.

4EF4518DEF8D4063BF3875F6EE0F1E04.description: Recall the matter, form, symbols and effects for each of the seven sacraments.

7C7D19FB00C1405ABED88223546C420B.description:
Articulate how the Sacraments strengthen their relationships with God and the faith
community and benefit both the individual and the community.

D30986EDABF9444BBB127DC3D7528239.description: List ways to more fully participate in the sacramental life of the Church.

881598D6AFDE4CC784DFA09C70F86610.description: Describe how liturgy expresses diversity and maintains unity today.

3EACC232E9664AE7AC2948B997D4943B.description: Describe all of the parts of the Mass and the role of the assembly.

4ABA7542C3974215B2287E29252FC263.description: Articulate how Eucharist is the source and summit of our faith.

A60749BE08CD403CA886A4F8E4CF3B90.description:
Recall and demonstrate the meaning of full, active and conscious participation in the
liturgy.

27F9DC4674C349DC9DEE6FA339909CB6.description:
EUCHARIST
 Who, How, When,
and Where the Mass
is Celebrated
[1135-1167, 1322-
1419]
Scripture:
Mt. 26:25-30
Mk. 14:12-26
Lk. 22:14-20
Jn. 6:32-58
Act 2:42-47

26C0DC82133941DCA2C4E7D0E6F9E635.description:
TASK OF CATECHESIS 2 – LITURGICAL EDUCATION: Students recognize the presence of Christ and enter into communion with Him through active, full and
conscious participation in the Liturgical celebrations and Sacraments of the Church.

A477A6EF951A48B9AEB8E5D612366F7B.description: Recognize the Nicene Creed came from early Church Ecumenical Councils.

E8F037550F6144FA994074BC4FA3AF33.description: Explain the purpose of the Nicene Creed in the Mass.

9517DB819409455284AA32E02E66BD25.description:
Demonstrate the ability to individually pray the Nicene and Apostles Creeds as
statements of belief.

21F88F0D4581430A85E5E9C468147404.description:
Identify the special charisms of the Church she receives from the Holy Spirit to
accomplish its work.

E9F9B7DBC32849C6970163396C8CE90D.description:
List the Gifts of the Holy Spirit, the purpose of each gift, and identify outward
expressions of those gifts.

6F13CD30D5B041D990B6AE21D244D9F9.description: Explore how the Holy Spirit continues to strengthen and animate the Church.

476975323B274B80B6F1B8C7B3156E04.description:
Describe how God is both transcendent (beyond our understanding) and
immanent (existing within) illustrated by the Old Testament passage of Moses and the Burning
Bush.

C6D038F25FD4465DA229EB1349DDC0AE.description:
Describe how God the Father sent the Son, Jesus, to redeem us and how the grace
of the Holy Spirit continues to give us new life.

259B9AE0E62D4B92B1B2F25007756C6F.description:
Recall that the divine persons are relative to one another, and that each is wholly and
entirely God.

A5DF1B0D6B23448AB6DBA4501BE560D8.description:
Describe the Trinity as a complete unity without confusing the persons or dividing
the substance of God.

B165028A234F40D7B05D96A2606DEE95.description:
TRINITY
God the Father, Creator
God the Son,
Redeemer
God the Holy Spirit,
Sanctifier
[249-324]
Scripture
Mt. 3:13-17
Acts 2:1-42
Ex. 3:1-17

02941B440D7F431CB6029BA765881824.description:
Describe how, inspired by the Holy Spirit, the Church continues the mission of
Jesus and continues showing God’s everlasting love through living out the Paschal Mystery.

991538E300604BD6A60DFE3FD0BD3D16.description:
Explain the concept and importance of the Incarnation, the Paschal Mystery, the
Resurrection and Ascension of Jesus Christ.

F380911E8D424AD59CF1C3082C352CF0.description:
Use the Gospels to understand Jesus’ ministry as one who teaches, forgives, and
heals in the name of the Father.

FDEF4C5480874A5FBA4FC6BE585A43E4.description: List and explain the ways the Church continues to teach as Jesus did.

291FD38DD07743658A638EBCA7EC576E.description: Explain the importance of Pentecost in the history of the Church.

8CBD6526C735434E9764839B25A595AD.description:
Demonstrate an understanding of Salvation History and identify how the Acts of
the Apostles, the epistles, and our lives today are a continuation of Salvation History.

7E2C28AFCCFE4707A6ECEEF56349EF80.description: Describe how Catholics read the Bible within the living Tradition of the Church.

1BF8974BB22F463FA860EFE2A0F059BA.description: Explain the role of the Holy Spirit in the writing and preaching of Sacred Scripture.

683C80A390964499A259160448270AFC.description:
Describe the connection between Scripture and Tradition and the true faith we find
in both that make up a single deposit of the Word of God.

DD45A657E63D40C4A584D31191A8EA97.description:
Understand how the Bible came to be written from the oral tradition to the canon
of Scripture.

EB06299AC4874C14AF4D43ADA73EB106.description:
Understand that revelation ended with the death of the last apostle, but continues to
be transmitted through Apostolic Tradition.

EBBF7159B62740CC8FDCA977FAFE9FA5.description:
Experience how God’s revelation includes the Natural Law, which is written in the
hearts of every person and helps us discern good and evil as disciples of Jesus Christ.

AFF09142864B4F0AB2408B459C2E53AD.description:
Describe how faith is both a personal relationship with God and a free assent to the
truth God has revealed.

EBD4F53A3C214B9092B84C7B130902EA.description:
Define faith as a gift we receive from God through the Church that helps us to believe
in and respond to God’s on-going revelation.

5C45AAF8AC734892B5F0411725F8E831.description:
Trace God’s revelation over time and human history as the foundation of our faith as
Christians.

CB4AC8DBC1F54A15A7E547DFFF89E39B.description:
TASK OF CATECHESIS 1 – KNOWLEDGE OF THE FAITH: Students explore, profess and reflect on our Catholic faith, which is the content of God’s revelation found in
Sacred Scripture and Sacred Tradition and lived out in the Creed and Church doctrine.
